verses.text: Jehoshaphat king of Judah returned safely to his house in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Faithful to Hebrew; 'returned in peace' rendered as 'returned safely' for clarity.

verses.text: Jehu the son of Hanani the seer went out to meet him and said to King Jehoshaphat, 'Should you help the wicked and love those who hate the LORD? Because of this, wrath has come upon you from the LORD.'
verses.comment: 'Should you help the wicked and love those who hate the LORD?' closely matches Hebrew phrase structure; clear judgment of Jehoshaphat’s alliance.

verses.text: 'Nevertheless, good things are found in you, for you have removed the Asherah poles from the land and have set your heart to seek God.'
verses.comment: 'Asherah poles' is a literal rendering for clarity; 'set your heart to seek God' maintains the idiomatic sense of Hebrew.

verses.text: Jehoshaphat lived in Jerusalem, and he went out again among the people from Beersheba to the hill country of Ephraim, and brought them back to the LORD, the God of their ancestors.
verses.comment: Geographical terms and 'ancestors' modernized for readability. 'He brought them back to the LORD' mirrors the restoration effort in Hebrew.

verses.text: He appointed judges throughout the land in all the fortified cities of Judah, city by city.
verses.comment: Phrase structure closely matches Hebrew; 'city by city' maintains the original distributive nuance.

verses.text: He said to the judges, 'Consider carefully what you do, for you do not judge for man but for the LORD, and he is with you when you render judgment.'
verses.comment: 'Consider carefully what you do' replaces 'see what you do' for clarity. 'Render judgment' is modern legal language.

verses.text: 'Now then, let the fear of the LORD be upon you. Be careful what you do, for there is no injustice, partiality, or bribery with the LORD our God.'
verses.comment: Bribery and partiality terms closely reflect Hebrew legal language; 'Be careful what you do' modernizes 'watch what you do.'

verses.text: Moreover, in Jerusalem Jehoshaphat appointed certain Levites, priests, and heads of families of Israel, to judge for the LORD and to settle disputes. They lived in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: 'Appointed certain Levites...' keeps wording structured like Hebrew; 'to settle disputes' explains purpose of their appointment.

verses.text: He commanded them, saying, 'This is how you shall act: in the fear of the LORD, faithfully, and with a whole heart.'
verses.comment: 'With a whole heart' maintains the idiomatic Hebrew phrase for sincerity.

verses.text: 'Whenever a dispute arises between your brothers who live in other cities — about bloodshed, law, commandment, statutes, or ordinances — you shall warn them not to sin against the LORD, so that wrath may not come upon you and your brothers. Do this, and you will not sin.'
verses.comment: Expanded list ('bloodshed, law, commandment, statutes, or ordinances') reflects specific Hebrew terms; 'Do this, and you will not sin' is a direct rendering.

verses.text: 'Amariah the chief priest will have authority over you in all matters of the LORD, and Zebadiah son of Ishmael, the leader of the tribe of Judah, in all matters of the king. The Levites will serve as officers before you. Be strong and act bravery, and may the LORD be with those who do what is good.'
verses.comment: Division of religious and civil matters carefully preserved. 'Act bravery' corrects to 'act bravely'; reflects Hebrew idiom for courage.
